'''Tinsley Ellis''' (born June 4, 1957)  is an American [[blues]] and [[rock music|rock]] [[musician]], who grew up in southern [[Florida]].

==Biography==
His love for electric blues grew by listening to [[British Invasion]] bands such as [[The Yardbirds]], [[The Animals]], [[Cream (band)|Cream]], and [[The Rolling Stones]].<ref name="AMG"/> Inspired by a live appearance by [[B.B. King]], he was determined to become a blues [[guitarist]]. In 1975, he played with the Haygood Band while attending Emory near Atlanta. Two years later, already an accomplished musician, he returned to Atlanta and joined his first band, The Alley Cats, a group that included Preston Hubbard of [[The Fabulous Thunderbirds]]<ref name="AMG"/> and Mike Marinelli, saxophonist who was a [[Berklee College of Music]] woodwind instructor. Ellis graduated from [[Emory University]] in 1979 with a degree in history. In 1981 he formed The Heartfixers, with the [[singer]] and [[harmonica]] player [[Chicago Bob Nelson]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 109–110
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> The group [[recorded]] three albums for the small Landslide [[record label]], one with the singer, [[Nappy Brown]] before breaking up in 1988.<ref name="russell"/> In 1988 Ellis signed a [[recording contract]] with Chicago’s [[Alligator Records]].<ref name="russell"/>  According to ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', “nobody has released more consistently excellent blues albums than Atlanta’s Tinsley Ellis. He sings like a man possessed and wields a mean lead guitar.”<ref name="Billboard">{{cite journal
| last = 
| first = 
| title = Billboard review
| pages = 
| newspaper = Billboard
| location = New York
| date = 26 June 2007
| url =http://www.billboard.com}}
</ref>

His debut solo album on Alligator Records, ''Georgia Blue'', was released in 1988.<ref name="AMG"/> Alligator then reissued two of his earlier CDs, ''Cool On It'' and ''Tore Up'' (featuring Nappy Brown). Ellis' next four releases were ''Fanning the Flames'' (1989), ''[[Trouble Time]]'' (1992), ''Storm Warning'' (1994), and ''[[Fire It Up (Tinsley Ellis album)|Fire It Up]]'' (1997).<ref name="AMG"/> [[Musician|Artists]] including [[Peter Buck]] (of [[R.E.M.]]) [[Derek Trucks]] and [[Chuck Leavell]] joined him in the [[recording studio|studio]]. He worked with [[record producer]]s, [[Eddy Offord]] and [[Tom Dowd]].
 
Ellis’ reputation and media coverage continued to grow. He appeared on [[NBC-TV]] Sports during the network’s [[1996 Summer Olympics]] coverage. [[Rolling Stone]] said, “On assertive originals and standards by the likes of [[Jimmy Reed]] and 
[[Junior Wells]], Atlanta's Tinsley Ellis unleashes feral blues guitar. Nonstop gigging has sharpened his six-string to a razor's edge…his eloquence dazzles…he also achieves pyrotechnics that rival early [[Jeff Beck]] and [[Eric Clapton]]."<ref name= "Rolling Stone">{{cite journal
| last = Evans
| first = Paul
| last2 = 
| first2 = 
| author2-link = 
| title = Storm Warning
| newspaper = Rolling Stone
| pages = 
| date = October 6, 1994
| url = http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/tinsleyellis/albums/album/155231/review/5941904/storm_warning
| accessdate =}}</ref>

Ellis shifted to [[Capricorn Records]] in 2000 and released ''[[Kingpin (Tinsley Ellis album)|Kingpin]]''. In 2002 he joined [[Telarc Records]], producing two CDs: ''[[Hell or High Water (Tinsley Ellis album)|Hell or High Water]]'' and ''[[The Hard Way (Tinsley Ellis album)|The Hard Way]]''. All the while Ellis never stopped touring. "A musician never got famous by staying home," Ellis says. Ellis claims to have performed live, at least once, in all 50 United States.

He returned to Alligator Records in 2005 with the [[live album]], ''[[Live:Highwayman|Live! Highwayman]]''. In 2007 he released the studio album, ''[[Moment of Truth (Tinsley Ellis album)|Moment of Truth]]'', followed in 2009 with ''[[Speak No Evil (Tinsley Ellis album)|Speak No Evil]]''.<ref name="AMG"/> Ellis continues to tour over 150 nights a year around the world.

He has shared stages with [[Warren Haynes]], [[Widespread Panic]], [[The Allman Brothers Band]], [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]], [[Jimmy Thackery]], [[Otis Rush]], [[Willie Dixon]], [[Son Seals]], [[Koko Taylor]], [[Albert Collins]] and [[Buddy Guy]]. He often plays smaller venues that allow the band a more personal contact with the audience.

==Discography==
*1986 - ''Cool on It'' (with The Heartfixers)
*1988 - ''Georgia Blue''
*1989 - ''Fanning the Flames''
*1992 - ''[[Trouble Time]]''
*1994 - ''Storm Warning''
*1997 - ''[[Fire It Up (Tinsley Ellis album)|Fire it Up]]''
*2000 - ''[[Kingpin (Tinsley Ellis album)|Kingpin]]''
*2002 - ''[[Hell or High Water (Tinsley Ellis album)|Hell or High Water]]''
*2004 - ''[[The Hard Way (Tinsley Ellis album)|The Hard Way]]''
*2005 - ''[[Live:Highwayman|Live! Highwayman]]''
*2007 - ''[[Moment of Truth (Tinsley Ellis album)|Moment of Truth]]''
*2009 - ''[[Speak No Evil (Tinsley Ellis album)|Speak No Evil]]''
*2013 - ''[[Get It! (Tinsley Ellis album (all Instrumental))|Get It!]]''
*2014 - ''[[Midnight Blue (Tinsley Ellis album)|Midnight Blue]]''
===Compilations===
*1996 - ''A Celebration of Blues: The New Breed''
